 This is not true. Scientific evidence comes two basic forms: empirical and predictive. Empirical evidence constitutes that which we observe. We can observe that certain people engage in sex exclusively with members of the opposite sex, while others do it exclusively with members of the same sex. This constitutes empirical evidence.
 
 If we conduct a scientific experiment observing three groups: one with a history of same-sex relationships, one with a history of opposite-sex relationships, and one with a random history, and conduct an experiment using the scientific method to predict their future sexual behavior, then we have predictive evidence of the existence of homosexuality.
 
 So I would say that we have a very large amount of evidence supporting the idea that homosexuality exists.
 
 However, what you might say is that science cannot prove that anyone is homosexual, heterosexual, or otherwise. You would be correct in that.
 
 Also, in the same fashion, there could be scientific evidence supporting the possibility of someone changing his or her orientation if we were able to observe past and present behavior or conduct a scientific experiment which changes someone's behavior.

But it is not true that the interpretation of that evidence which results is caused by a concious decision. An individual cannot choose what to believe and not to believe, just as you yourself cannot choose to believe that grass is purple.
 
 Regarding "faith", the term is used to mean many different things. Sometimes it is used to mean "belief without reason", which can happen, but although someone may hold a belief without reason, I don't believe an individual can hold a belief by choice. Religious people are also often described as having "faith", though in that case, the terminology is used incorrectly, for most religious people will tell you that they do indeed have real reasons for believing in God. Sometimes faith is confused with hope. And sometimes, faith is actually belief with good reason, for example, I might say "I have faith that Joebrummer will get the job done." In this case, I may believe Joebrummer will get the job done because I know him to be a hard worker and have noted his successes in the past.
 
 But none of these things indicate that an individual is able to choose his own beliefs.
 
 I am never coerced or sucked into believing something not because I choose against it but because no good logic or evidence was provided against it. And I know a better explanation. But take someone who has no opinion, take a child and teach him some belief. When learning that belief, he doesn't make a concious choice, he believes it because that's all he knows; he has no reason to believe otherwise.

An oft-used accusation against religious people by atheists is that religious people believe things without evidence. But that's not true--religious people believe what they believe because of what they experience, which IS evidence to them.
